intro: Piper silvivagum f. peruvianum, commonly known as the Peruvian pepper plant, is a member of the Piperaceae family and is native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring opposite, ovate leaves with a glossy surface. The plant produces small, clustered greenish-white flowers followed by elongated, fleshy berries that turn red when mature. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in cloud forests. Due to its ornamental value and potential medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in tropical gardens.
